captions.text:
How to Train Your Bird to Talk. Birds aren’t
like babies—you can’t expect them to pick

up speech just by babbling away at them. You
need a plan. You will need The right breed

of bird Time Treats and patience. Step 1.
If you haven’t already bought Tweety, pick

a breed that is known for its chattiness.
Amazon parrots and African greys are the gabbiest,

followed by macaws, male cockatiels, mynahs,
and parakeets. Female cockatiels, female budgies,

grass parakeets, rosellas, and canaries don’t
talk. Step 2. Once you’ve narrowed your

choices to a talkative breed, focus your attention
on choosing a bird that seems alert and interested

in what’s going on around him. These are
clues that he’ll make a good talker. Step

3. Get a young bird. Like the proverbial old
dog who can’t learn new tricks, an older

bird is going to have more trouble picking
up speech. Step 4. Give the bird a name that

is no more than two syllables. A longer name
reduces the chances that he will learn to

say his own name. Step 5. If you’re married
and/or have children, pick one person to teach

the bird. If several people are trying to
instruct the bird, it will only confuse it.

Birds learn more easily from women. Step 6.
Start training at the optimal time. For smaller

birds, that’s at four to six months. For
bigger birds, wait until they’re six to

twelve months. Don’t teach a bird to whistle
before training him to talk, or it will make

the speech lessons that much harder. Step
7. Start training by saying a few simple words

to Tweety, always using them under the same
circumstances. For example, you could say

“Good morning” every day when you first
rise, and you could reserve “Bye” for

when the bird can see you walk out the door.
Step 8. Repeat the words several times in

each instance. You want the bird to start
associating the sound you are making with

the context. Step 9. Give Tweety a treat every
time he repeats something you are teaching

him. Remember that birds don’t just repeat
what you want them to; they mimic sounds they

hear. So if you’re suffering a bout of loud
flatulence, or getting ready to rip someone

a new one, stay out of Tweety’s earshot.
Step 10. If Tweety has picked up a bad word,

washing his mouth out with soap won’t work.
But ignoring him when he repeats the word

will, because getting your attention is his
main incentive. Step 11. Now enjoy chatting

with your fine-feathered friend! Did you know
Talking birds often will imitate your phone’s

ring tone because they get a kick out of watching
you come running.

title: How to Train Your Bird to Talk

comments.text:
Ringtones, I haven't had that one yet, I have a Male Rainbow Lorikeet who 
WONT SHUT UP, LOL   His cage is situated in my hallway which is right next 
to the toilet and laundry, so.. When i Press the button on my Dryer to 
start, He Literally, Perfectly mimics the exact frequency of the beep, i 
sometimes can't tell if it's the dryer or not, i've had times when i was in 
a hurry i press the dryer button and i thought it was ON, i come back an 
hour later, the clothes are still wet.  LOL
then He Mimics the Creak in the toiler door,
i then put some WD-40 on and fixed the issue, but i sometimes thing it came 
back, but , it actually didn't , Rocky (my Bird) feels the need to make the 
Creaking noise everytime you enter or leave the toilet LOL
and then there's the air con,  When you press the button on the remote, he 
mimics the beep perferctly,  it really gets confusing
then.. He has copied the way we laugh (me and the wife), so sometimes when 
we are laughing, so does he, and we can't tell if it's us or them, it all 
sounds the same

Amazing BIrds,  You literally say something to him once, and he gets it,
He may not say it right away,
but.. in a few days it comes out.

he used to bite me hard when he was younger, and i used to point my finger 
and say STOP,  STOP ROCKY
My wife used to watch our arguments
Rocky has learnt to now say  STOP to me
in a way it's good, because if he bites too hard, i say  STOP and now he 
does
but, if i play with him to long, he gets pissed off and bites gently, and 
if i don't stop he just comes out and says  STOP
it's really cool
LOL
so.. after a pain staking experience , we now have a little language thing 
going on
and he doesn't bite anymore

I've lately taught him to take a shit in the morning IN THE TOILET BOWL, 
believe it or not
and it works,
He actually, if he can't take a crap,, He actually tries really hard to 
take a crap, because he feels proud to have done so in the toilet bowl

somes a very small drop comes out,
but hey.. You gotta praise him for it, He puts in so much effort to squeeze 
it out

Cute Little Bugger, But very smart indeed
i recommend Rainbow Lorikeets to anyone

but.. keep in mind
they require  A LOT OF ATTENTION
They take a shit every 15 mins or so,  Literally  Every 15 mins (think 
about it)
so.. teach him to get on your hand and take him to the toilet every 10 mins

YES.. EVERY 10MINS
or .. Put him in the cage and let him take a crap in the cage
and..
 they bite very very hard, I'm told they bite harder than most White 
Cockatoos or Gallahs
so.. be careful

but if you get through all that and you have patience, they are wonderful 
and a pleasure to have.﻿

comments.text:
Personally I would say the most important thing for teaching your bird to 
talk is treating them like a human instead of an animal. For example, keep 
them on a perch or activity center, not in a cage, eat at the same time as 
them and in the same room as them, tell them what you are doing all the 
time "mommy is making some food" etc , and spend as much time as you can 
beak to nose so they can feel the vibration of your words. Tell them "I 
love you" at least twice a day, then give them a kiss. Birds Love 
affection, even more than toys and they need a lot of attention to stay 
happy. Happy birds are talkative birds.﻿

comments.author: Waleed Khan

comments.text:
The things being said in this video are awful. These things are why there 
are so many rescues overfull of birds with problems like depression and 
self-harm. A bird is a LOT of work, and a very intelligent and emotionally 
sensitive creature. People don't realize how hard it is to take care of 
birds, it's very labor intensive and can require some creative thinking to 
work around things like "Oh, my bird thinks I'm his mate and is attacking 
anyone who gets near me with the intention to draw blood" without losing 
the birds trust or seriously harming it. If you think you know how to train 
birds because you know how to train dogs, think again. Now, if you managed 
to teach a cat to roll over, sit, stay, and meow on command, you might be 
ready to train a bird.﻿
